repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Closes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3426

-------------------------

~(I'm getting a segmentation fault on the fstring tests with the current master, which is making it difficult to run this through a thorough set of tests. It happens with and without this PR. I'm not sure where this is due to something being messed up on my side or a real bug, but I'll look into and report it separately. Just noting it here because it means I couldn't test this PR with with "runtest.py string")~ Caching issues to do with Cython.inline - I'd clearly ended up with a broken version cached - ignore

comment_data.body: Looks like the right place to fix this, but I think we should also allow `str_type` here if one side is `unicode_type`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -11364,13 +11364,8 @@ def compute_c_result_type(self, type1, type2):
                 self, type1, type2)
 
     def py_operation_function(self, code):
-        is_unicode_concat = False
-        if isinstance(self.operand1, FormattedValueNode) or isinstance(self.operand2, FormattedValueNode):
-            is_unicode_concat = True
-        else:
-            type1, type2 = self.operand1.type, self.operand2.type
-            if type1 is unicode_type or type2 is unicode_type:
-                is_unicode_concat = type1.is_builtin_type and type2.is_builtin_type
+        type1, type2 = self.operand1.type, self.operand2.type
+        is_unicode_concat = type1 is unicode_type and type2 is unicode_type

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
        self.assertEqual('a', y[0])
        self.assertEqual('b', y[1])
        self.assertEqual(['a', 'b'], y)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -993,6 +993,13 @@ class CommonTest(BaseTest):
         self.checkequal('\u019b\u1d00\u1d86\u0221\u1fb7',
                         '\u019b\u1d00\u1d86\u0221\u1fb7', 'capitalize')
 
+    def test_list_concat(self):
+        # https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3426
+        y = []
+        y += 'ab'
+        self.assertEqual('a', y[0])
+        self.assertEqual('b', y[1])

comment_data.body:
bytes + unicode doesn't work in Python 3 - try `u"ab" + b"cd"` and `b"cd" + u"ab"`.

In Python 2 it does work, and `PyUnicode_Concat` provides a quick path. I could probably add a `__Pyx_PyUnicode_ConcatStr` function (or similar) that goes to `PyUnicode_Concat` in Python 2 and `PyNumber_Add` in Python 3, but this seems a bit of a waste of time given that Python 2 support is soon to go.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -11364,13 +11364,8 @@ def compute_c_result_type(self, type1, type2):
                 self, type1, type2)
 
     def py_operation_function(self, code):
-        is_unicode_concat = False
-        if isinstance(self.operand1, FormattedValueNode) or isinstance(self.operand2, FormattedValueNode):
-            is_unicode_concat = True
-        else:
-            type1, type2 = self.operand1.type, self.operand2.type
-            if type1 is unicode_type or type2 is unicode_type:
-                is_unicode_concat = type1.is_builtin_type and type2.is_builtin_type
+        type1, type2 = self.operand1.type, self.operand2.type
+        is_unicode_concat = type1 is unicode_type and type2 is unicode_type

comment_data.body: However... there is one optimization it might actually be worth looking into here (although only tangentially related to this bug). CPython has a specific optimization to check the reference count of the RHS and append rather than concat if possible: https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/309d7cc5df4e2bf3086c49eb2b1b56b929554500/Python/ceval.c#L5354
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -11364,13 +11364,8 @@ def compute_c_result_type(self, type1, type2):
                 self, type1, type2)
 
     def py_operation_function(self, code):
-        is_unicode_concat = False
-        if isinstance(self.operand1, FormattedValueNode) or isinstance(self.operand2, FormattedValueNode):
-            is_unicode_concat = True
-        else:
-            type1, type2 = self.operand1.type, self.operand2.type
-            if type1 is unicode_type or type2 is unicode_type:
-                is_unicode_concat = type1.is_builtin_type and type2.is_builtin_type
+        type1, type2 = self.operand1.type, self.operand2.type
+        is_unicode_concat = type1 is unicode_type and type2 is unicode_type

comment_data.body:
> bytes + unicode doesn't work in Python 3

Note: I wrote `str_type`, not `bytes_type`. They are different things in Cython. (Exactly for cases like this.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -11364,13 +11364,8 @@ def compute_c_result_type(self, type1, type2):
                 self, type1, type2)
 
     def py_operation_function(self, code):
-        is_unicode_concat = False
-        if isinstance(self.operand1, FormattedValueNode) or isinstance(self.operand2, FormattedValueNode):
-            is_unicode_concat = True
-        else:
-            type1, type2 = self.operand1.type, self.operand2.type
-            if type1 is unicode_type or type2 is unicode_type:
-                is_unicode_concat = type1.is_builtin_type and type2.is_builtin_type
+        type1, type2 = self.operand1.type, self.operand2.type
+        is_unicode_concat = type1 is unicode_type and type2 is unicode_type

comment_data.body:
Is there a reason why we need to look at the `language_level` here?
ISTM that all we need is 1) one of `type1` and `type2` is `unicode_type`, and 2) the other is either `unicode_type` or `str_type`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -11364,13 +11364,13 @@ def compute_c_result_type(self, type1, type2):
                 self, type1, type2)
 
     def py_operation_function(self, code):
-        is_unicode_concat = False
-        if isinstance(self.operand1, FormattedValueNode) or isinstance(self.operand2, FormattedValueNode):
-            is_unicode_concat = True
-        else:
-            type1, type2 = self.operand1.type, self.operand2.type
-            if type1 is unicode_type or type2 is unicode_type:
-                is_unicode_concat = type1.is_builtin_type and type2.is_builtin_type
+        language_level = code.funcstate.scope.global_scope().context.language_level
+        type1, type2 = self.operand1.type, self.operand2.type
+        # in Py2 str_type is bytes but this can be concatted to a unicode_type string.
+        # in Py3 str_type is unicode so can be concatted to unicode_type or str_type
+        is_unicode_concat = (type1 in (unicode_type, str_type) and type2 in ((unicode_type, str_type))
+                                and not (type1 is str_type and type2 is str_type
+                                         and language_level == 2))

comment_data.body: I wonder if removing this special case can lead to regressions. Doesn't seem very likely, given that f-strings are always built from unicode string parts. But I don't remember all the optimisations that apply to these parts along the way. Not all of them may be aware of the concrete result type in order to preserve it along the way.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -11364,13 +11364,8 @@ def compute_c_result_type(self, type1, type2):
                 self, type1, type2)
 
     def py_operation_function(self, code):
-        is_unicode_concat = False
-        if isinstance(self.operand1, FormattedValueNode) or isinstance(self.operand2, FormattedValueNode):
-            is_unicode_concat = True

comment_data.body: As far as I could tell the result type of `FormattedValueNode` was permanently set to `unicode_type` anyway, so it seemed fairly safe. Also, it'd be (probably fairly small?) performance regression rather than than anything breaking (`PyNumber_Add` does work). I can definitely put it back in if wanted, but it seems more likely to cause bugs then fix them.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -11364,13 +11364,8 @@ def compute_c_result_type(self, type1, type2):
                 self, type1, type2)
 
     def py_operation_function(self, code):
-        is_unicode_concat = False
-        if isinstance(self.operand1, FormattedValueNode) or isinstance(self.operand2, FormattedValueNode):
-            is_unicode_concat = True

comment_data.body:
This seems more of a CPython-only optimisation than a not-PyPy thing.
(And it feels worth a separate PR.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2553,3 +2553,101 @@ static PyObject *__Pyx_PyMethod_New(PyObject *func, PyObject *self, CYTHON_UNUSE
 #else
     #define __Pyx_PyMethod_New PyMethod_New
 #endif
+
+/////////////// UnicodeConcatInplace.proto ////////////////
+
+#if CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_PYPY || PY_MAJOR_VERSION == 2

comment_data.body: OK - backed it out again. I'll submit it as a separate PR.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2553,3 +2553,101 @@ static PyObject *__Pyx_PyMethod_New(PyObject *func, PyObject *self, CYTHON_UNUSE
 #else
     #define __Pyx_PyMethod_New PyMethod_New
 #endif
+
+/////////////// UnicodeConcatInplace.proto ////////////////
+
+#if CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_PYPY || PY_MAJOR_VERSION == 2

comment_data.body:
> seems more likely to cause bugs then fix them.

`FormattedValueNode` should only originate from f-strings, and they always produce string parts that are then joined in one way or another. That seems safe. The question is just if the new "unicode or str" decision below succeeds for all of those parts, including operands that are no longer `FormattedValueNode`s themselves (but return a unicode string at runtime).

This PR seems like a fix that should go into 0.29.x, really, in which case I'd like to reduce the risk of regressions a bit more than strictly necessary. I don't think it hurts to keep the `isinstance()` tests, at least in that branch.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -11364,13 +11364,8 @@ def compute_c_result_type(self, type1, type2):
                 self, type1, type2)
 
     def py_operation_function(self, code):
-        is_unicode_concat = False
-        if isinstance(self.operand1, FormattedValueNode) or isinstance(self.operand2, FormattedValueNode):
-            is_unicode_concat = True

commit.message:
Only used PyUnicode_Concat on unicode objects

https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3426

parent f8e396843b52f5758bdffcbfe2088a6c4643c42d
author da-woods <dw-git@d-woods.co.uk> 1584373952 +0000

Update tests/run/test_unicode_string_tests.pxi

Co-Authored-By: Stefan Behnel <stefan_ml@behnel.de>

commit.message: Optimized for string_type as well as unicode_type

Optimized (some) inplace operations

Optimized inplace operations for bytes and unicode so that they're
genuinely done in place if no-one else needs the object. This
is what CPython tries to do (and was a string concatenation was
a point where it significantly beat Cython at times)

This only works if the types are known at compile time, so with
unknown types CPython will still be faster in some cases

Revert "Optimized (some) inplace operations"

This reverts commit 7d2608ecb96c6e4194490c6804368b41a2591ba7.

Corrected choice with str_type

Better if unicode concat is done with more settings of str_type
Refactor conditions to make them more extensible and (hopefully) also clearer.

title: Only used PyUnicode_Concat on unicode objects
